column3: > Why?\n\nEven if we don't persist the console windows content, one may not want to expose private keys (and the wallet passphrase) on the screen. IMO "shell"-like interpreters should never reveal passwords "on screen" after they have been typed-in.

Quickly tested. Used the same command with both `importprivkey("some_key")`.
Using master (12af74b289f8cdc6caf850dc6c802f9936b1e8b3) command params are displayed on screen.
With this PR (7278537), they are not. 
Master:
![master](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/863730/24586694/54f7bc68-17d9-11e7-9ddd-e47a785ad1e3.png)

This PR:
![10093](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/

> Even if we don't persist the console windows content, one may not want to expose private keys (and the wallet passphrase) on the screen. IMO "shell"-like interpreters should never reveal passwords "on screen" after they have been typed-in.

Agree, it is somewhat useful to prevent shoulder-surfing.

Concept ACK.
ACK 72785377306764ab999e4bab13b821e4e5ea11eb.\n\nCode change is trivial. Tested and confirmed it removes arguments onscreen in addition to ones in history (which were already removed before).
